que tu sentido común y tu corazón te aconsejan 
rendirte, cuando nada se parece a lo que has imaginado 
ni a lo que te han dicho o has leído, y también cuando 
tu propio sueño se desmorona ante la realidad de tu 
poco valor y tu escaso talento... Pero es ése el 
momento en el que debes vencer y en el que debes 
decirte que hay que seguir, porque luego comprendes

1Resumen
Losinsectossaproxílicossonungrupomuydiversoquedesempeñaunpapelclaveen
elprocesodereciclajedenutrientesenlosbosques,siendoconsideradocomogrupo
bioindicadordelacalidadyestadodeconservacióndelhábitat.Ademásreúneun
amplionúmerodeespeciesbajoalgunacategoríadeamenazasegúnloscriteriosdela
UICN.
Conestatesisdoctoralsepretendeporprimeravezaportardatossobrelos
insectossaproxílicos(ColeopterayDiptera:Syrphidae)delosecosistemasdedehesa
deloesteibérico,habiéndosedesarrolladolasinvestigacionesenelmarcodelproyecto
LIFE-Nature Conservación de la Biodiversidad en el Oeste Ibérico
(LIFE/E/NAT/000762) y del proyecto  Estructura de la comunidad y factores
ambientalesquecondicionanlapresenciadeinsectossaproxílicos:efectodelacalidad 
delhábitatenlosensamblesdeColeopterayDipteradebosquesmediterráneos 
(MinisteriodeCienciaeInnovaciónCGL2009-09656 /BOS).ElproyectoLIFEsurgió
antelanecesidaddecontarconunmodelodegestióndelosecosistemasdedehesadel
oesteibéricoquepermitiesemantenerlabiodiversidaddeestoshábitatsincluidosen
laRedNatura2000conelfindecontribuirasuconservación. 
Elobjetivogeneraldeestatesisdoctoralesportantodaraconocerpor
primeravezladiversidadyestructuradelosensamblesdelasespeciesdecoleópteros
ysírfidossaproxílicosdelasdehesas,tantoaescalaespacialcomotemporal, yponer
demanifiestolaimportanciadeesteecosistemamediterráneoenelmantenimientode
ladiversidaddeestegrupodeinsectos.
EltrabajodecamposellevóacaboenlaReservaBiológicadeCampanariosde
Azaba,localizadaenelsudoestedelaprovinciadeSalamanca,España.Setratadeun
ecosistemaconelpaisajetípicodedehesasalmantina,dondepredominanlosárboles

ThedehesaisatraditionalIberianagrosilvopastoralecosystemcharacterizedbythe

favorthepresenceofawiderangeofbiodiversity.Weshowthehighdiversityof
saproxylic beetles and syrphids (Diptera) in this ecosystem, including red-listed 
species.Weanalyzedwhethersaproxylicspeciesdistributioninthedehesawas

54Introduction
Human activities have developed a peculiar agrosilvopastoral ecosystem, which
dominatesthelandscapeinthesouth-westernIberianPeninsula.Thisecosystemi s
calleddehesainSpainandmontado"inPortugal,andcoversapproximately3.5 -4.0
millionhectaresinwesternSpain(SanMiguel1994;Oleaetal.2005)and0.7million
hectaresinPortugal(Pereiraetal.2004).TheSpanishtermdehesa (fromtheLatin
worddefesa)appearsforthefirsttimeinthe10thcentury,referringtoareasusedfor
pastureandrearinglivestock,mainlybullsand/orIberianpigs(Klein1920)andthese
practicesarecurrentlystillinuse(García-González1979;Gómez-Gutiérrez1992).
Despitetheoriginandmaintenanceofthedehesabeingduetolivestockandfarming
uses,huntingactivitieshavealsotakenplace,thuscreatingdifferentareaswithlower
andhighershrubcoverageinthedehesa(Cabo1976). 
This ecosystem is the result of the transformation of the original
Mediterranean forest by clearance and brushwood removal to introduce cattle,
providingatypicallandscapeofsavannah-likeopenwoodlandwithscatteredtrees
(Camposetal.2013).Traditionalpracticesinthedehesa,suc hasclear-cutstands,
producedifferentsuccessionalstagesandanever-changingland-usemosaicwithhigh
socioeconomic and conservation values (Díaz et al. 1997; Bugalho et al. 2011).
Accordingtoitslong- termhistoryofmanagement,thedehesa isconsideredasa
well-establishedculturallandscape(Díazetal.1997),andisincludedintheHabitat
Directive(AnnexI6310Dehesaswithevergreen Quercusspp)andalsoinNatura
2000Network(www.natura.org/).
Thedominanttreesindehesas areQuercusspecies(Hernández1995;Joffre
etal.1999;López-Sáezetal.2007;Llorente-Pinto2011)thataredistributedinlow
density,varyingbetween20and50trees/ha,inordertoobtaingoodacornproduction
forlivestock(Vázquezetal.1999;PulidoandDiaz 2005).Usually,treesinthedehesa
havealargediameterrelatedtotheageandopennessoftheecosystem(Plieningeret
al.2003).Thisscatteredtreedistributionisoneofthemainfactorsthatdeterminethe
richnessandabundanceofanimaldiversit yinthedehesa(Gómez -Gutiérrez1992;

55Díazetal.1997).Thetreesarealsoconsideredtobekeystone -structures(Manning
etal.2006),astheyprovidefoodresourcesandrefugeforawiderangeofanimals
(Tewsetal.2004).
Upuntilnow,onlysomegroupshavebeenstudied:mammals(MaloandSuárez
1995),birds(PulidoandDíaz1992;Díaz2003),lizards(MartínandLópez2002),ants
(Reyes-Lópezetal.2003),CalliphoridDiptera(Martinez-Sánchezetal.1998),dung-
beetles(Galanteetal.1991;1994;1995)andCarabids(Taboadaetal.2006;2010).
However,saproxylicinsectshavebeenpoorlystudiedinthedehesa(seeMicóetal.
2010;2011a;Viñolas2012),inspiteoftheirdependenceonmaturetrees.
Saproxylicinsectsarekeyorganismsinthetrophicchainofforestsdueto their
high diversity and biological diversification (Stokland et al. 2012). In general,
ColeopteraandDiptera(Syrphidae)arethebestrepresentedamongsaproxylicinsects
(Dajoz1998)andtheyalsoincludeahighpercentageofthreatenedspecies(Nietoand
Alexander2010;Radenkovi etal.2013).Moreover,manyofthem(i.e.beetles)are
involvedinimportantecosystemservices,suchasbreakingdowndeadwoodand
recyclingnutrients(Dajoz1998;ThompsonandRotheray1998;Brustel2001;Micóet
al.2011b;Stoklandetal.2012).
Micóetal.(2011a)revealedthatscatteredtreesinthedehesawithalong -
termhistoryofmanagementwereanimportantreservoirofendangeredsaproxylic
beetlesandsyrphids.However,untilnow,nostudyhasanalyzedthewidesaproxylic
communityofthedehesaandhowitsmanagementaffectsitsdiversity.Themai n
goal of this study wasto analyze the distribution of saproxylic Coleoptera and
Syrphidaeassemblagesinaprotecteddehesaecosystem fromthewesternIberian
Peninsula,andtoassesstheeffectsoftreedensityonthedistributionoftherichness
andabundanceofColeopteraandSyrphidaesaproxylicspecies.Wealsoanalyzedthe
possibleinfluenceofdominanttreesspeciesandvegetationcoverageonspecies
diversityandcompositionofbothtaxa.Theuseoftwosaproxylictaxawithdifferent
dispersalabilities,habitatandfoodrequirements,wastoprovideabroaderviewof
howlandscapemanagementcouldaffectsaproxylicdiversity.

Discussion
PreviousstudiescarriedoutincentralSpain(CabañerosNationalPark)assessing
saproxylicassemblages(Micóetal,2013;Quintoetal,2013)haveshownsimilar
valuesofspeciesrichness.Thehighdiversityofsaproxylicbeetlesandsyrphid s(136
and16speciesrespectively)fromthedehesa ecosystemispresumablyrelatedtothe
dynamismoftheecosystem,duetoitslonghistoryofagrosilvopastoralmanagement ,
whichhasgeneratedhighlandscapeheterogeneityandarichmosaicofhabitats
(MontserratandFillat1990;Gómez-Saletal.1992;Fahrigetal.2011).Itiswellknown
thatsaproxylicinsectdiversityisfavoredbythepresenceofoldandlargetrees
(Lindheetal.2005;Stoklandetal.2012),becausetheyoffermicrohabitatsforawide
rangeofspecies(Speight1989;WarrenandKey1991;Faytetal.2006;Ricarteetal.
2009),andoldmanagedtreesareabundantinthedehesa ecosystem(Joffreetal. 
1999;Llorente-Pinto2011).Thelong- termhistoryofmanagementinthedehesa has
shapedascatteredtreelandscapewithalowdensity(about20-50trees/ha),thus
CAPITULOII.LADEHESA,UNECOSISTEMACLAVE
 
 
70allowingtheformationoftreeswithalargediameter(Plieningeretal.2003).Several
studieshavedemonstratedthatthediameteroftreesispositivelyrelatedtospecies
richness(Jonselletal.1998;RaniusandJansson2000;Grove2002).Moreover,
traditionaltreemanagement(pollardingandlighterpruning)promotestheformation
ofhollows(Sebeketal.2013),thusincreasingmicrohabitatsforsaproxylicfauna
(Alexander2003).Intheabsenceofprimaryforest,allofthesefactorscoulddetermine
thattheselong-termmanagedlandscapesactassaproxylicreservoirstoalargeextent,
evenforred-listedspeciessuchas Limoniscusviolaceus ,whichhaveshownthemost
westernpopulationinEuropehere(Micóetal.2011a)or Mallotadusmeti ,whichis
restrictedtoSpainandtheTunisianRepublic(ClaussenandHauser1990)andwas
wellrepresentedinthestudiedarea.
With a total of 3.5- 4 million hectares in Spain, the dehesa ecosystem
representsabout7%oftheterritoryinCastillaandLeón(MonteroandSerrada2013)
andingeneral,15%ofthetotalproductiveareainSpain(Pérez-Sobaetal.2007).
Dehesaisamosaichabitatwithhighspatialheterogeneityasaresultofagricultural
practices,livestockhusbandry,forestryandhuntingactivities(Moreno-Marcos etal.
2007;PulidoandPicardo2010;Camposetal.2013).Inthisway,brushwoodcoverage
changesamongsites(i.e.areasdestinedforhuntingusuallyhaveahighervaluefor
brushwoodcoverage)andthedominanttreespeciesalsovaries.
Saproxylicrichnesswassignificantlyaffectedbydominanttreespeciesand
brushwoodcoverage,butnotinthesamewayforColeopteraandDiptera,dueto
differences in their ecological requirements. Saproxylic beetle assemblages were
significantlyaffectedbydominanttreespecies.Beetleassemblagesweremorelinked
toQ.pyrenaica thanQrotundifolia, andthiscanbeexplainedbythestructural
differencesbetweenbothtreespecies,forexample,in Qpyrenaica thetreehollow
volumewasgreater(0.057m3)thaninQrotundifolia (0.014m3).Thesecharacteristics
derivedfromthetypeofmanagement(pollardandpruning)used,whichhasbeen
strongerinthepastfor Q.pyrenaica andhasgeneratedmanylargertreehollows(Fig
1b),thusenhancingthemicrohabitatofthesaproxylicbeetles(Speight1989;Bougetet

71al.2005).Inthisway,Quintoetal.(inreview)haveassessedtheresponseofsaproxylic
beetlestothemicroenvironmentalvariablesaccordingtotrophicguilds,determining
thatbeetlediversityisinfluencedbyhigherhollowvolumes.Despite Q.rotundifolia 
exhibiting larger diameters, the tree hollows hosted were smaller (Fig 1a) and
normallyfilledwithwater(pers.obs.),thusrepresentingafavorablehabitatformany
syrphidlarvaethatareaquaticorsemiaquatic(RotherayandMacGowan2000;Faytet
al.2006;Speightetal.2010).Thiscouldexplainthehigherrichnessofsyrphidsrelated
toQ.rotundifolia inthisarea.
TheresponseofColeopteraandDipterarichnesstoshrubcoveragewasalso
different.Itiswellknownthatmanyspeciesonlyexhibitsaproxylichabitsforpartof
theirlife.Thisisthecaseofallsaproxylicsyrphidspecies,whoselarvaelivein tree
hollowsbutwhoseadultsneedtovisitsuitablesourcesofpollenandnectarforfeeding 
(ThompsonandRotheray1998).Ourresultsshowthatthemainvariableaffecting
syrphidswasshrubcoverage,andindeedspeciesrichnessofsyrphidswasfavoredby
highershrubcoverage(30-90%),wherefloristicrichnesswasalsohigher.Inabroad
sense,thepresenceofshrubsalsoincreasessaproxylicbeetlerichness(Øklandetal
1996;Janssenetal.2009).
However,beetlerichnesswassimilaratbothshrubcoveragelevelsinthe
studiedarea,andwasonlyslightlyhigherinareaswithlowershrubcoverage(5-25%)
(Fig.2b).ThetrophichabitsofadultsaremorediverseinColeopterathaninSyrphids,
whichcouldbewhyitispossiblethattheresponseofallthesaproxylicbeetle
assemblageswouldseemtobelessaffectedbythisvariable.Differencesinspecies
turnoverwereonlyfoundbetweenthedominanttreespeciesforsaproxylicbeetles
(Table3).Alloftheseresultsseemtoindicatethat,ingeneral,themainfactordriving
saproxylicdiversityisrelatedtothetreespeciesanditsmanagement.
Inthisway,wealsofoundthattenbeetlespecieswereindicatorsfortree
species,eightfor Q.pyrenaica speciesandonlytwofor Q.rotundifolia (Table5).
Cerambyxwelensii (IndVal84.7%; p0.003)mainlyattacksickanddecrepittreesand,
asexplainedbefore, Q.pyrenaica wasthespeciesmostaffectedinthisareaby

Conclusions
TheDehesaecosystem,includedintheHabitatsDirectiveandalsoinNatura2000 
Network(www.natura.org/),hasbeenproventobearichreservoirofsaproxylic
insects,duetothemaintenanceinthisecosystemoflargemanagedtreesthatoffera
widerangeofmicrohabitatsforsaproxylicinsects.
Traditionalmanagementofthisecosystemdevelopsspatialheterogeneityand
habitatdiversification,thuscreatingaMediterraneanlandscapethataffectssaproxylic
diversitypositively.Akeypointisthatrichnessofdifferenttaxarespondsinadifferent
waytovegetationstructureandtreespeciesandcouldevendeterminespecies
compositioninColeoptera.Conservationstrategiesfordehesaecosystemsshouldtry 
tomaintaintraditionalmanagementinordertoconservehabitatheterogeneity,and
differentsaproxylictaxa(withdifferentrequirements)shouldalsobeusedtomonitor
theeffectofmanagementonsaproxylicdiversity.

CAPÍTULOIII.VARIACIÓNTEMPORAL
 
 
93Abstract
Oneofthemainchallengesinbiologicalconservationhasbeentounderstandspecies
distribution across space and time. In the last decades, many diversity and
conservationsurveyshavebeenconductedthatrevealthathabitatheterogeneityacts
asakeypatternthatmodelssaproxylicassemblages.However,temporaldynamics
havebeenpoorlystudied,especiallyinMediterraneanforests.Weanalyzedsaproxylic
beetledistributionatinterandintra- annualscalesinadehesaecosystem.Significant
differencesineffectivenumbersoffamilies/speciesandspeciesrichnesswerefoundat
inter-annualscale,butthiswasnotthecaseforcomposition.Temperatureandrelative
humiditydidnotexplainthesechanges;nevertheless,thisvariationwasmainlydueto
thepresenceofrarespecies.Atintra-annualscale,significantdifferencesineffective 
numbersoffamilies/species,speciesrichnessandcompositionbetweenseasonsw ere
found,anddiversitypartitioningrevealedthatseasonscontributedsignificantlyto
gamma-diversity.Saproxylicbeetleassemblagesexhibitedamarkedseasonalitywith 
two peaks of activity, the highest between May-June and the second between
September-Octoberrelatedtoabundancebutnotinspeciesrichness.Thispatternis
mainlydrivenbytheseasonalityoftheclimateintheMediterraneanregionthat
influences ecosystem dynamics and imposes a marked seasonality on insect
assemblages.Anextendedsamplingperiodoverdifferentseasonsallowedanoverview
of saproxylic dynamics, and revealed which families/species were restricted to
particularseasons.Recognizingthatseasonsactasadriverinmodellingsaproxylic
beetleassemblagesmightwellbeavaluabletoolinmonitoringandconservation
strategiesinMediterraneanforests.

specialattentiontosaproxylicspeciesastheyareaverydiversifiedgroup(Stockland
etal.2012)thatconstitutekeyorganismsintheecologicalprocessesofforests,
especiallyintheprocessofrecyclingnutrients(Dajoz1998;Brustel2001;Micóetal.
2011).Furthermore,saproxylicbeetlespecieshavebeenparticularlyaffectedby
loggingandclearanceasaconsequenceofunsuitablemanagementofforestsoverthe
lastdecades(Grove2002)andtheyareoneofthelargestgroupsofinsectsincludedin
theredlists(NietoandAlexander2010).
In a broad sense, species richness and composition at both spatial and
temporalscalescouldbetakenintoaccountasakeytounderstandingthestructureof
saproxylicbeetleassemblages(Sobeketal.2009);nevertheless,knowledgeatsuch
scalesisstilllimited(Sverdrup-Thygesonetal.2014).
Atspatialscale,habitatheterogeneityiswidelyrecognizedasakeypattern
drivingsaproxylicbeetleassemblagesinnorthern(Tewsetal.2004;Sobeketal.2009;
Bougetetal.2013)andMediterranean(BrinandBrustel2006;Siramietal.2008;Micó
etal.2013)Europeanforests.Moreover,theeffectsofcertainenvironmentalpatterns
onsaproxylicbeetles,suchasmicrohabitatavailability(WinterandMöller2008;
Vuidotetal.2011),forestopenness(Widerbergetal.2012),sun-exposureandtree
diameter(Kailaetal.1997;Jonselletal.1998;Lindheetal.2005;HorákandRébl
2013)havealsobeenstudiedindepth.
Otherwise,studiesconcerningtemporalscalearescarceandgenerallyfocuson
evaluatingeffectivenessoftraps(e.g.MartikainenandKaila,2004),orontheevolution
ofbeetleassemblagesafterforestfires(GroveandForster,2011a;b;Boucheretal.
2012)orwindstormdisturbance(Wermelingeretal.2002;BougetandDuellib2004;
Bouget2005a;b).

95Despite recognition of the importance of studying temporal changes in
saproxylicspeciesassemblages(Sverdrup-Thygesonetal.2014);studiesofthistype
arestillveryscarceinMediterraneanforests.AsoccursinthenorthofEurope
(NageleisenandBouget2009),samplinginMediterraneanforestscommonlyconsists
ofashortperiodoftimethatmayevenbeasingleseason,inordertocoverthemain
activitymonthsandthereforetemporalcomparisonsacrosstheyeararelimited.
InnorthernEurope,samplingeffortshavebeenconcentratedinbothspring
andsummerseasons,whenthehighestpeaksofactivityareobserved(Nageleisenand
Bouget2009).Untilnow,nostudieshaveconsideredthewinterinEuropeanforests,
duetoitsextremelylowtemperatures,whichthereforemeanlowornoinsectactivity.
Incontrast,theMediterraneanclimateismainlycharacterizedbywarmanddry
summerswherethehottestdayscanreach35or40ºC;itscooltomildandwetwinters
wherethecoolestdayscanbe-3or-5ºC,withthemainprecipitationsfallingduring
thewintermonths(Blondeletal.2010).Accordingly,anextendedsamplingincluding
thewintercouldbecarriedoutduetotheseclimaticconditions,inordertocoverthe
fullvegetationperiodand,inthisway,toobtainanoverviewofthewholesaproxylic
assemblage.
Afirstattempttoimprovetheknowledgeofthetemporaldistributionof
MediterraneansaproxylicbeetlesassemblagehasrecentlybeendemonstratedbyBuse
etal.(2013),wheresamplingwasconductedduringthehighestactivityperiod(March
toSeptember).Twopeaksofannualactivitywereobservedforbothspeciesrichness
andabundance,whichoccurredinMayandtheAugust-Septemberperiodrespectively
(seeBuseetal.2013).
Themaingoalofthisstudywastoanalyzethepossiblechangesinsaproxylic
beetleassemblagesattwotemporalscales(bothinterandintra- annual)inadehesa
ecosysteminwesternSpain.Inordertoassesstemporalshifts,effectivenumbers,
species richness, abundance and composition were taken into account at two
taxonomic levels: families and species. To explore the changes in saproxylic
assemblagesatinter-annualscale,westudiedwhethertherewasacorrelationwith

expectedlowershiftsineffectivenumbersoffamilies/speciesrichnessandconti nuity
intaxacompositionbetweenthetwoyearssampled.Incontrast,significantchanges

97Samplingdesign
Window traps (WT) were used due to their effectiveness in the monitoring of
saproxylic flying beetles associated with different tree microhabitats and their
surroundingfauna(Økland1996;Bougetetal.2008;Quintoetal.2013).ThirtyWT
weredistributedacross13samplingunitsthatwereselectedcoveringthewhole
extensionofthereserveandthepotswerereplacedmonthlyfromApril2010to
November2011.
Atinter-annualscale,thedatasetsfromtwoconsecutiveyearswereselected
correspondingtothemonthsfromApriltoNovember2010(T1)andthesameperiod
fromApriltoNovember2011(T2).Atintra-annualscale,changesinsaproxylicbeetle
communitiesindifferentseasonswereassessedbyusingonlythedatasetfromone
samplingyear(12months),fromDecember2010toNovember2011.
Recordingenvironmentaldata
Temperatureandrelativehumidity(RH)wererecordedwithHOBOU23Prov2
Temperature/RelativeHumidityDataLogger-U23-001.Elevendataloggerswere
placedonthetrunksofelevendifferenttrees,justoutsidethehollowopeningsand
werethenprogramedtorecordtemperatureandRHdataevery4hoursthroughout
thetwoyearsampleperiod.
Speciesidentification
SeveralEuropeanspecialistsinsaproxylicbeetlescollaboratedinspeciesidentification
(see acknowledgements) and nomenclature was according to Fauna Europaea
(http://www.faunaeur.org/),Bouchardetal.(2011)andtheCataloguesofPalearctic
Coleoptera (Löbl and Smetana, 2004; 2006; 2007; 2008). The specimens were
depositedintheEntomologicalCollectionoftheUniversityAlicante(CEUA).

98Dataanalysis
We estimated the average of both monthly temperature and RH to assess the
differencesbetweenbothyearssampled,andanalyseswereperformedwithaKruskal-
WallistestusingPastsoftware(Hammeretal.2001).TheSpearmanRankOrder
Correlation test was performed with STATISTICA software v7
(http://www.statsoft.com/)inordertoevaluatewhetherbothabioticfactorsaffected
thesaproxylicbeetleassemblagesbetweenyears.
Completeness of the families/species inventory per sampling unit was
evaluatedasthepercentageofobservedspeciesinrelationtothenumberofspecies
predictedbybothrichnessestimators:oneabundance-basedandtheotherincidence-
based(Chao1andChao2,respectively);analyseswereperformedwithEstimateS®
softwarev8(Colwell2008;50randompermutations).
Comparisonoffamilies/speciesrichnessbetweenyearsandamongseasons
studiedtookplaceusingindividual-basedrarefactioncurveswith95%confidence
intervals, and analyses were performed with EcoSim software v7 (Gotelli and
Entsminger2004).Also,theeffectivenumbersoffamilies/specieswerecalculated
usingthemeasureoftruediversityorder1(Jost2006),whichweightseachspecies
accordingtoitsfrequencyinthecommunity(e.g.favoringneitherrarenorcommon
species). Given the presence of rare species (singletons) in the study area, we
estimateddiversityusingtheChaoandShenestimator(ChaoandShen2003)using
SPADEsoftware(ChaoandShen2010).
Differencesinspeciescompositionwereestimatedasaninversemeasureof
turnoverbycalculatingtheJaccardSimilarityIndex([JSI]Jaccard1912;Magurran
2004),whichisbasedontherelationshipofpresence-absencebetweenthenumberof
commonspeciesintwosampleunitsandthetotalnumberofspecies(KentandCoker
1992).Ananalysisofsimilarity(ANOSIM;Faithetal.1987)wasperformedtotestthe
significanceofthesedifferencesusingPRIMERv6(ClarkeandGorley2006).

112Discussion
Inter-annualshiftsofsaproxylicassemblages
Ourresultsshowedsignificantdifferencesrelatedtofamiliesandspeciesrichness
betweenthetwoconsecutiveyears,butthiswasnotthecaseforfamiliesandspecies
composition.Itiswellknownthattemperatureandprecipitationinfluencesaproxylic
beetleactivity(Kelner-Pillault1974;Stoklandetal.2012),however,inourstudy,
differences in the average temperature and RH between both years were not
significant.Accordingly,themaindifferencesfoundinspeciesrichnessbet weenthe
twoyearscouldbeexplainedbyotherfactors,suchashabitatcontinuity(Winterand
Möller2008),whichallowstheexistenceofvariationsinpopulationdynamicsthatdo
notrepresentsignificantchangesatcompositionlevelfortheassemblage,andalsodue
tothep resenceoftouristand/orrarespecies(MartikainenandKaila2004).Infact,
ourresultsshowedthatmostofthefamiliesandspecieswhichwerenotregisteredi n
oneofthestudiedyearsweresingletonsordoubletons,withveryfewexceptionssuch
asDorcatomaagenjoi , which was only collected during the first year with 16
specimens(Fig.2a;b;Appendix).
Somesaproxylicbeetleshavelowdispersalability(Thomas2000;Raniusand
Hedin2001;EwersandDidham2006),aresmallandcryptic(Bougetetal.2008)or
exhibitspecialpreferencesforparticularmicrohabitatsofferedbytreesspeciesin
forests(Dajoz1980;Siramietal.2008;WinterandMöller2008),andarethen
representedbylowabundance;moreover,oftentherarityofmanyspeciesmightbe
relatedtoaninappropriatesamplingmethod.
Asexpected,thechangesintheassemblagebetweenyearswasrelatedto
rarespecies,andtheaverageofthoserarespecies(34.3%)waslowenoughto
generatesignificantdifferencesinspeciescompositionbetweenyears.Inthiss ense,
MartikainenandKouki(2003),MartikainenandKaila(2004)andParmainetal.
(2013)havenoticedthattherecordofthesespeciesincreaseswhensamplingeffortis
increasedbyusinglong-termmonitoring;however,evenalargesamplingperiodof10

113yearscouldrepresentaperiodoftimethatistooshorttoappreciatestrongvariations
insaproxylicassemblages.
Shiftsofsaproxylicdiversityamongseasons
InnorthernEuropethetypicalpeakofdiversityhasbeenlinkedtolatespringand
earlysummerandsamplingeffortisoftencomprisedfromApriltoOctoberinorderto
coverthemajorperiodofactivityofsaproxylicbeetleassemblages(Brustel2001;
Wermelingeretal.2002;Wikarsetal.2005;NageleisenandBouget2009).Incontrast,
boththespringandautumnareseasonsthatrepresentcommonpeaksofdiversityin
Mediterraneanareas,whichhavebeenreportedformanyinsecttaxa(Blondeland
Aronson1999;Zamoraetal.2007)includingsaproxylicbeetles,ashasrecentlybeen
provenbyBuseetal.(2013).
Theseasonalityfoundinsaproxylicbeetlesspeciescouldbedeterminedbythe
Mediterraneanclimatefeatures,whichshowsapatternofacombinationofwarmand
drysummers,andcooltomildwetwinters(Blondeletal.2010).Ourresultsshowed
thatseasonalityofsaproxylicbeetleassemblagesisstronglymarkedbyaheavyfallin
speciesrichnessandabundanceinsummer,relatedtohightemperaturesandlowRH
(Fig.5b).Themainpeakofadultactivity(speciesrichnessandabundance)wasfou nd
attheendofspringoratthebeginningofsummer(dependingontheyear).Thislow
asynchronybetweenyearscouldbeexplainedbyslightdifferencesintemperatures
andRH(Fig.5a)thatmaydeterminethestartofactivity(seeKelner-Pillault1974;
Franc2007;GroveandForster2011a,whereitisstatedthatclimateinfluencesspecies
dynamics).Howeverthesecondpeakinautumnisclearinabundancebutnotalways
inrichness,withspeciesrichnesslowerthaninwinter.Thispatternisstillmore
marked in the dehesa ecosystem studied, which is open forest, where canopy
coverageisabout50%ofcoverageandtreedensityrangesfrom16to69trees/ha
(average39trees/ha)(Ramírez-Hernándezetal.2014),sosun-exposureishighall
yearround.

114Speciesrichnessandcompositionofsaproxylicbeetleassemblagesvaried
significantlybetweenseasons,anddiversitypartitioningalsogavesimilarresults ,
whichmakesitclearthattherateofchangeinspeciesturnoverbetweenconsecutive
monthsislow,whereasturnoverwassignificantlyaffectedbyseasons(Fig.4),which
act as a driver influencing saproxylic beetle dynamics inMediterranean forests .
Furthermore,thisseasonalvariationmightberelatedtodifferencesinlife-cycles
(Gaylordetal.2006)andthereforemanyspeciesmightonlydisperseactivelyasadults
forashortperiodoftime,andcouldthenonlyberecordedinconcreteseasons,suchas
spring-summer(e.g.Cetoniidae,Cerambycidae),autumn-winter(e.g.Tetratomidae)or
theymayavoidthehotmonthsofsummerandshowaconsiderabledecreaseintheir
abundance(e.g.Cryptophagidae)(Fig6a;b).
WeconcludethatthestronglymarkedseasonalityoftheMediterraneanregion
(stillmoreconspicuousinthiskindofforestduetoitsopenness)modelssaproxylic
beetleassemblages,whichshowahighspeciesturnoveramongseasons.Anextended
sampling period throughout the year has revealed highseasonal preferences in
familiesandspecies,whiledifferencesamongtwoconsecutivesamplingyearsare
found in the effective numbers ofspecies richnessand abundance. The gamma
diversity was the result of high beta diversity between seasons, therefore, the
temporalscaleshouldbeconsiderednotonlyforspeciesmonitoringbutalsofor
speciesandhabitatmanagement.

CAPÍTULOIV.ANALIZANDOLAESTACIONALIDAD
 
 
133Resumen
Losensamblesdecoleópterossaproxílicosmediterráneospresentanunamarcada
estacionalidad.Enestecapítuloseanalizalavariacióntemporaldeladiversidad
(riquezayabundancia)decoleópterossaproxílicosatendiendoadiferentesaspectos
funcionales:elementosbiogeográficos,tallacorporaldelasespeciesygremiostróficos.
Observamosquelamayorriquezadeelementosbiogeográficossonmediterráneo
centralycentroeuropeos.Existeunmayorporcentajederiquezadeespeciesentre
primavera-verano,siendomayorainiciosdelaprimavera,mientrasqueenotoñolos
elementosmayoritariossonlosqueposeenunaampliadistribucióngeográficaqueva
desdeelnortedeÁfricahastaOrientePróximoextendiéndoseportodalazonanortey
centroeuropea. Los resultadosmuestran que el tamaño del cuerpo resulta poco
eficientecomopredictordelaabundanciadeespecies.Sinembargo,encuantoala
variacióndeltamañocorporalentreestaciones,eselveranodondeseencuentranlas
especies de mayor talla, mientras las especies más pequeñas están distribuidas
durantetodoelaño,alcanzandosusmáximospicosdeabundanciaenotoño.El
ensamble de los gremios tróficos a través de las estaciones mostró diferencias
significativasanivelderiquezaendepredadoresyaquelamayorriquezadeespecies 
ocurre durante la primavera y verano. A nivel de abundancia, los xilófagos y
depredadoresmuestranmayoresvariacionesestacionalessiendolosxilófagosmás

134Introducción
Unodelosprincipalesretosenlabiologíadelaconservaciónesentendercuálesson
losfactoresquedeterminanlariqueza,abundanciaycomposicióndeespeciesatravés
del espacio y del tiempo. En estesentido, con el fin de generar estrategias de
conservaciónapropiadas,lamayoríadelosestudiossobrecoleópterossaproxílicos
hansidoenfocadosdesdelaperspectivaespacial,debidoalaregresióndesushábitats
durantelasúltimasdécadas(Grove2002);sinembargo,elconocimientoaescala
temporalesaunlimitado(Sverdrup-Thygeson etal.2014).
Lascondicionesbióticasyabióticasnosonconstantesalolargodeltiempo,por
loquelavariaciónenladisponibilidadderecursos,combinadaconloscambiosdel
climaquedeterminanlascondicionesquerigenlasestacionesdelaño,influyenenlas
dinámicaspoblacionalesdelasespeciesenlosecosistemas(Southwood etal.2004)e
imponeunamarcadaestacionalidadenlacomunidaddeinsectosengeneral(Wolda
1988)yenladeloscoleópterossaproxílicosenparticular(ver capítuloIII).Eneste
sentido,lamarcadaestacionalidadqueexhibelafaunasaproxílicaestáensincronía
conlascaracterísticasdelclimamediterráneo(vercapítuloIII),quepresentauna
temporadaestivalmuymarcadaenlaquelastemperaturasdelosdíasmáscalurosos
puedenalcanzarlos35o40ºC;mientrasquelosinviernossonhúmedosyfríos
registrandobajastemperaturasquepuedenllegara-5ºC(Blondel etal.2010).

diversidad de coleópteros saproxílicos, ya que permite el paso de la luz solar
incrementandolaactividaddelasespecies(Kaila etal.1997;Jonsell etal.1998;Lindhe
etal.2005;Widerberg etal.2012;Horák&Rébl,2013).Enestesentido,elpaisajedel
oeste ibérico está dominado por la dehesa, un ecosistema típico de usos

abiertomediterráneodondelacoberturadeldoselesbastanteuniforme(50%dela
cobertura)conárbolesaisladosenbajadensidad(capítuloII),porloquelaapertura

135permiteunamayorexposicióndelaluzsolar(Moreno-Marcos etal.2007;Montero et

deloscoleópterossaproxílicosyaque,talycomosemuestraenelcapítuloIII,no
existe una relación estadísticamente significativa entre dichas variables con la

quepermitenaciertasespeciesdesarrollarseendeterminadasestacionesdelaño
dondeexistemenosactividadbiológicacomolosmesesinvernales(Brown etal.2004;
Verdúetal.2007;Stokland etal.2012).

ciertainformaciónsobresutoleranciatérmica(Verdú&Lobo2008),deformaque

Discusión
Nuestrosresultadosrevelanquelosensamblesdecoleópterossaproxílicosexhibenun 
patrónestacionalqueseveinfluenciadoenciertogradoporeltamañocorporal,
distribucióngeográficaylasbiologíasdelasespecies,determinandosusdinámi cas
temporales,aunquenosiempredeformaestadísticamentesignificativa.Puedenser
muchoslosfactoresqueexpliquenestosresultados,yaseaanivelfisiol ógico,climático,
biogeográficoorelacionadoconlashistoriasdevidadelasespeciesyquizáestas
variablesdebanserevaluadasaunamenorescala.

148Engeneral,nuestrosresultadoshanpermitidoobservarquelasespeciesde
mayortamañomuestranunatendenciaasermenosabundantesyviceversa.Eltamaño
corporalylaabundanciadelasespeciesdecoleópterossaproxílicosserelacionande
maneranegativa,sinembargo,estacorrelaciónnoesestadísticamentesignificativ a.
Este resultado que coincide con otrosestudios en los que se han evaluado los
ensamblesdediferentesgruposdeinsectos,incluidoscoleópteros,ydeigualmanera,
paralagranmayoríadeestosgruposlacorrelaciónhasidodébilonoexiste(Morse et
al.1988;Blackburn etal.1990;Blackburn etal.1993);porlotanto,eltamañodel
cuerporesultapocoeficientecomopredictordelaabundanciadeespecies(Blackburn
etal.1990;Peters1991).
Generalmente,lasespeciesdemayortallacomo C.welensii(46ind;46.3mm),

19.73mm), E.ferrugineus (12ind,19.41mm)fueronmásabundantesduranteel

mm),Epuraeafuscicollis (Stephens,1835) (43ind;3.51mm), C.scanicus(37ind;2.15
mm)mostraronsusmáximospicosdeabundanciaduranteelotoño.Estasdiferencias
en la actividad versus tamaño del cuerpo pueden estar relacionadas con las
característicasfisiológicasdelasespecies,pudiendoserelreflejodeunaspropiedades 
biológicasquecondicionanlasmáximasabundanciasregistradasdeespeciesdemayor
tamañoduranteelverano(Fig.3).Essabidoqueespeciesdemayortamañopresentan

devuelo(Verdú&Lobo2008).Estopuedeestardeterminadoporlascondiciones

The old trees of Iberian «dehesa», an important reservoir of threatened

rareandendangeredspeciesdepending,ondifferentways,onawidevarietyof
microhabitatsrelatedwithdecayingwoodasthehollowsofveterantrees.Inthe
Mediterraneanforests,manysaproxylicColeopteraandDipteraspeciesarelinkedto
thispeculiarmicrohabitatandoftentheirpopulationscansurviveinatransformed
landscapewhenscatteredoldtreesarepreserved.Inthispaper,weshowforfirsttime
the importance of the maintenance of veteran trees and the traditional tree
managementinatypicalIberian«dehesa»(grasslandwithscatteredoaktrees)forthe
conservationofThreatenedandNearThreatenedsaproxylicspecies.Thestudyhas

saproxylic species [ Limoniscus violaceus  (Muller, 1821) (Coleoptera: Elateridae),
Eupotosiamirifica  (Mulsant, 1842) (Coleoptera: Cetoniidae) and Mallotadusmeti 
Andréu,1926(Diptera:Syrphidae)]andtwoNearThreatened[( Elaterferrugineus 
Linnaeus, 1758 (Coleoptera: Elateridae) and Cerambyx cerdo  (Linnaeus, 1758)
(Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)], at European level, has been reported. This report

Losbosques,yenparticularlasformacionesmaduras,sonunobjetivobásicodelos
programasdeconservacióndebiodiversidad,entreotrosmotivos,poralbergaruna
grancantidaddemaderamuerta(enpieyensuelo)queconstituyeunaabundante
fuentedealimentoyrefugioparanumerososorganismoscomomicromamíferos,aves ,
insectos,hongos,etc.(MARCOS etal.,2010).Lacomunidadsaproxílicaabarcaun
amplioabanicotaxonómicoqueincluyeasuvezdistintosgruposfuncionaleslig adosa
lamaderamuerta.Entreellosencontramosaquellosquesealimentandirectamentede
lamadera,losquedependendeloshongosasociadosalamisma,delosexudadosde
savia,oinclusolosquedepredanaotrosorganismossaproxílicos(SPEIGHT,1989).En
definitiva, los invertebrados saproxílicos constituyen el mayor porcentaje de la

de estos insectos en los ecosistemas forestales, radica en su contribución a la
fragmentación de los restos de madera, tanto por su acción mecánica como
indirectamente a través de relaciones endosimbiónticas con hongos y otros

Esprecisamentesuestrechaasociaciónalosbosqueslaprincipalcausadeque
losinsectossaproxílicosseanenlaactualidadunodelosgrupostaxonómicosmás
amenazadosenEuropacomoconsecuencia,principalmente,delasprácticasforestales
delosúltimos200años(BERG etal.,1994;READ,2000;ALEXANDER,2004;SPEIGHT,
1989;NIETO&ALEXANDER,2010).Anteestasituación,enelConveniodeBernasobre
lavidasilvestreeuropea(AnexoII)serecogióporprimeravezinformaciónsobre

laUICN(IUCNRegionalOfficeofEuropeyIUCNSpeciesProgram)yapeticióndela
ComisiónEuropea,seelaborólaprimeraListaRojadeColeópterosSaproxílicos
